full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, John. How are you feeling about today's session?
Client: I... I'm not sure. Part of me wants to get this over with, but another part is terrified. It's like my stomach is in knots.
Therapist: That's understandable. Let's start with a SUDS rating.
Client: Uh, probably around a 6 or 7 right now.
Therapist: Okay. Remember, we'll go at your pace. Are you ready to begin?
Client: I guess so. Yeah, let's do this.
Therapist: Close your eyes and take us back to that day.

Client: (Deep breath) Okay... I'm... I'm 15 again. It's a Saturday morning, and I'm at the community center. The... the cult leader, he calls himself "Father Michael," he's there. He's smiling at me, but it doesn't reach his eyes. God, I can smell his cologne from here. It's sickly sweet.
Therapist: Stay with that moment. What happens next?
Client: He... he puts his hand on my shoulder. Says he needs to talk to me privately. I follow him to his office. My heart's racing. I know something's wrong, but I can't... I can't disobey him.
Therapist: You're doing well. What's your SUDS level now?
Client: It's... it's climbing. Maybe an 8?
Therapist: Take a deep breath. Remember, you're safe here.

Client: (Shaky breath) Okay... We're in his office now. He locks the door. I can hear the click. It's so loud. He turns to me and says... he says I've been chosen for a special blessing. But his eyes... they're hungry.
Therapist: Stay present. What do you see, hear, feel?

Client: I see his desk. It's dark wood, polished. There's a photo of him with some important-looking people. I hear muffled voices outside, kids laughing. But in here, it's so quiet. I feel... God, I feel sick.
Therapist: You're doing great, John. Keep going.

Client: He... he tells me to sit on the couch. It's leather, cold. He sits next to me, too close. His hand is on my knee. I want to run, but I can't move. He's talking about purity and sacrifice, but his words are blurring together.
Therapist: What's happening in your body right now?
Client: My hands are sweating. My chest feels tight. I... I think I might throw up.
Therapist: Take a moment. Ground yourself. Feel your feet on the floor.
Client: (Deep breaths) Okay... okay. I'm... I'm still here.
Therapist: When you're ready, continue.

Client: He... he starts to unbutton my shirt. His hands are cold. I'm frozen. I can't speak, can't move. He's saying it's God's will, that I'm special. But I feel... I feel dirty. Ashamed. Like I'm betraying everything I believe in.
Therapist: Remember, this wasn't your fault. What's your SUDS level?
Client: It's... it's a 9. Maybe higher. I can't...
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're safe here, John.

Client: (Shaky breath) He... he touches me. Places I've never been touched before. I want to scream, but no sound comes out. I'm crying, silently. He tells me this is our secret, that no one will understand. That if I tell anyone, I'll be cast out, damned.
Therapist: You're showing incredible strength. How are you feeling?
Client: I feel... I feel like I'm there again. But also... angry. So angry.
Therapist: It's okay to feel angry. Let's pause for a moment. Take some deep breaths.
Client: (Breathing deeply) Okay... I'm... I'm back in the room with you.
Therapist: Good. Do you want to continue or take a break?
Client: I... I think I need to keep going. To get it all out.
Therapist: Alright. When you're ready, return to the memory.

Client: After... after he's done, he prays over me. Like nothing happened. Like he didn't just... (voice breaks) He tells me I'm blessed now, that I should be grateful. I feel sick. I can barely stand. When I leave his office, everyone's still going about their day. No one knows. No one can see how broken I am inside.
Therapist: You're doing incredibly well, John. What's your SUDS level now?
Client: It's... it's still high. Maybe an 8.
Therapist: That's okay. Keep going if you can.

Client: I... I go home. I can't look my parents in the eye. I shower for hours, but I still feel dirty. I can't sleep that night. Or the next. Every time I close my eyes, I see his face. Feel his hands. I start having nightmares. Panic attacks. But I can't tell anyone. I'm trapped.
Therapist: How does your body feel as you remember this?
Client: Tense. So tense. My jaw hurts from clenching it. My stomach's in knots.
Therapist: Try to relax your muscles. You're safe now.
Client: (Exhales slowly) It's hard. It's like my body still remembers.
Therapist: That's normal. Keep breathing. What happened in the days after?

Client: I... I started withdrawing. From my family, my friends. I couldn't stand to be touched. I flinched at every sound. My grades started slipping. I couldn't focus. And every Saturday, I had to go back. Face him again. Pretend everything was normal.
Therapist: That must have been incredibly difficult. What's your SUDS level?
Client: It's... it's coming down a bit. Maybe a 7 now.
Therapist: Good. You're doing great, John. Keep going.

Client: This went on for... for months. Every week, the same thing. Sometimes worse. He'd... he'd make me do things to him. Say it was part of my "training." I felt so powerless. So trapped. I started thinking about... about ending it all.
Therapist: I'm glad you're here now. You survived.
Client: Yeah... yeah, I did. But sometimes I wonder at what cost.
Therapist: Those feelings are valid. What happened to end the abuse?

Client: It... it was my mom. She noticed the changes in me. Kept asking what was wrong. One day, I just... broke down. Told her everything. She was... she was devastated. Angry. But not at me. She went to the police that same day.
Therapist: How did that make you feel?
Client: Terrified. Relieved. Like a huge weight was lifted, but also like my world was ending. The cult... they turned against us. Called us liars, sinners. We had to move away.
Therapist: That must have been a huge upheaval. What's your SUDS level now?
Client: It's... it's down to a 5, I think. Talking about it... it helps, somehow.
Therapist: That's great progress. How do you feel about what happened now?
Client: I'm... I'm still angry. At him, at the cult, at myself sometimes. But I'm also... proud, I guess? That I survived. That I'm here, talking about it. It doesn't control me as much anymore.
Therapist: That's a powerful realization. Let's start winding down. Take some deep breaths.
Client: (Breathing deeply) Okay... I'm... I'm back in the room with you. Fully.
Therapist: Well done, John. That was incredibly brave of you.
Client: Thank you. It... it wasn't easy, but I feel... lighter, somehow.
Therapist: That's often the case. How are you feeling overall?
Client: Drained, but... okay. Better than I expected, actually.
Therapist: That's great to hear. Let's end with a final SUDS rating.
Client: I'd say... maybe a 3 now? It's much better.
Therapist: Excellent progress. We'll pick up here next session. For now, take care of yourself.
Client: I will. Thank you... for everything.
